node.title: Convergence problems in solving Poisson equation with Poisson-Boltzmann relation
node.bodyText:
I am trying to solve the Poisson's equation for electrical potential in a system containing positively and negatively charged ions,
$$\nabla ^2 \phi = - \rho/ \epsilon = - e(c^+ - c^-)/\epsilon$$
where $c^+$, $c^-$ are the concentrations given by
$$c^{\pm} = N \exp\left[\frac{ A^{\pm} \pm e\phi }{kT}  \right]$$
where $A^{\pm}, N, kT, e, \epsilon$ are constants.
I used the Diffusion and the MaskedBodyForce kernels (in the phase field module) for phi. The MaskedBodyForce is used for the $-\rho/\epsilon$ term. I am getting a convergence problem: Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_BREAKDOWN iterations
Since the problem is very non-linear, I used a gradual ramp-up with time for the MaskedBodyForce term by defining function = 't/10' and running the simulation till end_time=10.0. This does not converge beyond the first iteration. The input and output files are in https://github.com/ahzeeshan/moose-issue/tree/main/poisson
I am using similar values for the constants as a paper where they solved the equation in MATLAB.
I also wanted to confirm: the material m in the MaskedBodyForce can be a function of the variable phi, right?

Hi, the preconditioning matrix seems to be very poor. You can check this by decreasing the size of the problem and running -snes_test_jacobian. I was able to get some convergence by switching to PJFNK. My edits to your input are below. I see that you're using the DerivativeMaterialInterface so I wouldn't expect your matrix to be so poor, but I don't really use that feature much myself. Perhaps @dschwen could see what's wrong at a glance
diff --git a/modules/phase_field/user-problem.i b/modules/phase_field/user-problem.i
index 16bb511818..318ec1186b 100644
--- a/modules/phase_field/user-problem.i
+++ b/modules/phase_field/user-problem.i
@@ -2,7 +2,7 @@
   [./mesh]
    dim = 1
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
-   nx = 100000
+   nx = 10000
    xmax = 100e-9
   [../]
 []
@@ -119,18 +119,19 @@
   type = Transient
   scheme = bdf2
   verbose = True
-  solve_type = 'Newton'
-  l_max_its = 50
-  l_tol = 1e-6
-  nl_max_its = 50
+  solve_type = 'PJFNK'
+  l_max_its = 300
+  l_tol = 1e-2
+  abort_on_solve_fail = true
+  nl_max_its = 30
   nl_rel_tol = 1e-8
   nl_abs_tol = 1e-12
 #  petsc_options = '-snes_monitor -ksp_monitor_true_residual -snes_converged_reason -ksp_converged_reason'
 #  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_gmres_restart -sub_ksp_type -sub_pc_type -pc_asm_overlap'
 #  petsc_options_value = 'asm      31                  preonly      lu          4'
 #  line_search = 'none'
-  petsc_options_iname = -pc_type
-  petsc_options_value = asm
+  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_gmres_restart -pc_factor_mat_solver_type'
+  petsc_options_value = 'lu      300                superlu_dist'
   start_time = 0.0
   end_time = 10.0
   dt = 1.0

When you use the material_properties argument you need to be careful, when those properties depend on non-linear variables. To ensurer propper chain rule derivatives read up here: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/source/materials/DerivativeParsedMaterial.html the section following

The "material_property_names" are parsed by the FunctionMaterialPropertyDescriptor class, which understands the following syntax:

for example the cpos block should look like this
  [cpos]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    property_name = cpos
    material_property_names = 'dfepos(phi) N kT'
    expression = 'N * exp(-dfepos/kT) '
    derivative_order = 2
    coupled_variables = 'phi'
    outputs = other
  []

What if you have nested dependencies, for instance rhobyeps depends on cpos and cneg which depend on dfeneg/pos which depend on phi? I tried
@@ -63,7 +63,7 @@
   [./cpos]
     type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
     property_name = cpos
-    material_property_names = 'dfepos N kT'
+    material_property_names = 'dfepos(phi) N kT'
     expression = 'N * exp(-dfepos/kT) '
     derivative_order = 2
     outputs = other
@@ -71,7 +71,7 @@
   [./cneg]
     type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
     property_name = cneg
-    material_property_names = 'dfeneg N kT'
+    material_property_names = 'dfeneg(phi) N kT'
     expression = 'N * exp(-dfeneg/kT) '
     derivative_order = 2
     outputs = other
@@ -79,7 +79,7 @@
   [./rhobyeps]
     type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
     property_name = 'rhobyeps'
-    material_property_names = 'cpos cneg e eps'
+    material_property_names = 'cpos(phi) cneg(phi) e eps'
     expression = 'e*(cpos - cneg)/eps'
     derivative_order = 2
     outputs = other

and the Jacobian is still not good
Oops, I hadn't added coupled_variables. With that addition, the Jacobian now looks perfect

So in summary, the working patch is
diff --git a/modules/phase_field/user-problem.i b/modules/phase_field/user-problem.i
index 16bb511818..6878f02beb 100644
--- a/modules/phase_field/user-problem.i
+++ b/modules/phase_field/user-problem.i
@@ -63,25 +63,28 @@
   [./cpos]
     type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
     property_name = cpos
-    material_property_names = 'dfepos N kT'
+    material_property_names = 'dfepos(phi) N kT'
     expression = 'N * exp(-dfepos/kT) '
     derivative_order = 2
+    coupled_variables = 'phi'
     outputs = other
   [../]
   [./cneg]
     type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
     property_name = cneg
-    material_property_names = 'dfeneg N kT'
+    material_property_names = 'dfeneg(phi) N kT'
     expression = 'N * exp(-dfeneg/kT) '
     derivative_order = 2
     outputs = other
+    coupled_variables = 'phi'
   [../]
   [./rhobyeps]
     type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
     property_name = 'rhobyeps'
-    material_property_names = 'cpos cneg e eps'
+    material_property_names = 'cpos(phi) cneg(phi) e eps'
     expression = 'e*(cpos - cneg)/eps'
     derivative_order = 2
     outputs = other
+    coupled_variables = 'phi'
   [../]
 []

@@ -119,18 +122,18 @@
   type = Transient
   scheme = bdf2
   verbose = True
   solve_type = 'Newton'
-  l_max_its = 50
-  l_tol = 1e-6
-  nl_max_its = 50
+  l_max_its = 300
+  l_tol = 1e-2
+  nl_max_its = 30
   nl_rel_tol = 1e-8
   nl_abs_tol = 1e-12
 #  petsc_options = '-snes_monitor -ksp_monitor_true_residual -snes_converged_reason -ksp_converged_reason'
 #  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_gmres_restart -sub_ksp_type -sub_pc_type -pc_asm_overlap'
 #  petsc_options_value = 'asm      31                  preonly      lu          4'
 #  line_search = 'none'
-  petsc_options_iname = -pc_type
-  petsc_options_value = asm
+  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_gmres_restart -pc_factor_mat_solver_type'
+  petsc_options_value = 'lu	  300		     superlu_dist'
   start_time = 0.0
   end_time = 10.0
   dt = 1.0

node.title: Restart and Recover
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE experts,
I would like to use the result file from the previous task as the initial condition, but it won't run. Could you please help me check if there are any issues with my input file?
The original input file
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 2
  nx = 200
  ny = 200
  nz = 0
  xmin = 0
  xmax = 200
  ymin = 0
  ymax = 200
  zmin = 0
  zmax = 0
[]

[Variables]
  [./w]
  [../]
  [./eta]
  [../]
  [./pot]
  [../]
[]

[Functions]
  [./ic_func_eta]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = 0.5*(1.0-1.0*tanh((x-20)*2))
  [../]
  [./ic_func_c]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = 0
  [../]
  [./ic_func_pot]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = -0.225*(1.0-tanh((x-20)*2))
  [../]
[]

[ICs]
  [./eta]
    type = FunctionIC
    variable = eta
    function = ic_func_eta
  [../]
  [./w]
    type = FunctionIC
    variable = w
    function = ic_func_c
  [../]
  [./pot]
    type = FunctionIC
    variable = pot
    function = ic_func_pot
  [../]
[]

Input file for continuing calculation
[Mesh]
  file = c01_out.e
[]

[Variables]
  [./w]
    family = LAGRANGE
    order = FIRST
    initial_from_file_var = w
    initial_from_file_timestep = 245
  [../]
  [./eta]
    family = LAGRANGE
    order = FIRST
    initial_from_file_var = eta
    initial_from_file_timestep = 245
  [../]
  [./pot]
    family = LAGRANGE
    order = FIRST
    initial_from_file_var = pot
    initial_from_file_timestep = 245
  [../]
[]

Thank you.
HelloI see two initialization methods here, ICs and the initial-from-file.You can only use one

First, I calculated c01_out.e using the first input file. Then, I used c01_out.e as the initial condition and continued the calculation with the second input file. But it didn't even finish the first step and stopped running.
I plan to repeat this step many times.

Nevermind that 's not the problem.
In the second simulation, use a FileMeshGenerator in the [Mesh] block and set the use_for_exodus_restart parameter to true

I tried, but it still doesn't work.
the second input file
[Mesh]
  [./fmg]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = 'c01_out.e'
    use_for_exodus_restart = true
  [../]
[]

[Variables]
  [./w]
    family = LAGRANGE
    order = FIRST
    initial_from_file_var = w
    initial_from_file_timestep = 245
  [../]
  [./eta]
    family = LAGRANGE
    order = FIRST
    initial_from_file_var = eta
    initial_from_file_timestep = 245
  [../]
  [./pot]
    family = LAGRANGE
    order = FIRST
    initial_from_file_var = pot
    initial_from_file_timestep = 245
  [../]
[]

hello
what error do you get?
Does time step 245 exist in the file? Do you get a better result with LATEST instead of 245?

Time Step 0, time = 0
Time Step 1, time = 0.02, dt = 0.02
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_MAX_IT iterations 20
Currently Executing
Finished Solving                                                                       [ 34.41 s] [  178 MB]
Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge
Time Step 1, time = 0.01, dt = 0.01
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_MAX_IT iterations 20
Finished Solving                                                                       [ 28.42 s] [  182 MB]
Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge
Time Step 1, time = 0.005, dt = 0.005
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LINE_SEARCH iterations 16
Finished Solving                                                                       [ 24.37 s] [  182 MB]
Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge
Time Step 1, time = 0.0025, dt = 0.0025
Stuck here. It neither reports an error nor runs here.

The first input file
first.docx
The second input file
second.docx
The article I am referring to is
2023-ACS AMI.pdf

I think some of your materials have state.
Exodus restart does not restart those. So maybe that brings your simulation in an invalid configuration upon restart (first input works fine right?)
To restart materials with state, you need to use the checkpoint restart. See the restart recover documentation page to see how to do that

My first input file is running normally.
I am running the input file with added checkpoints restart. How to restart after running is completed? Do you have any examples?

There are examples of checkpoint restart in moose/test/tests/restart.
This one too :  restart in moose/test/tests/time_steppers/timesequence_stepper/timesequence_restart1.i

There's a problem.
Time Step 0, time = 112.721
WARNING! There are options you set that were not used!
WARNING! could be spelling mistake, etc!
There is one unused database option. It is:
Option left: name:-i value: f02.i source: command line
f02.i
[Mesh]
file = c02_checkpoint_cp/6750-mesh.cpr
[]
[Problem]
restart_file_base = c02_checkpoint_cp/6750
allow_initial_conditions_with_restart = true
[]

Hello
This is just a warning you can ignore it.
Why do you have allow_initial_conditions during restart set? Whichever initial condition you have set overrides the restarted values.
So it s ok but only if the restarted and initialized variables are diffeeent

I made a mistake in end_time. Now it can run.
Thank you very much for your patience.

node.title: How to link external libraries to a MOOSE application2.0
node.bodyText:
If I have an external library(*.a, *.so), how can I build it with MOOSE app together?
Let me show a simple example:
Create 2 C source files:
fun1.c
#include <stdio.h>
void fun1()
{
  printf("This is fun1!\n");
}
fun2.c
#include <stdio.h>
void fun1()
{
  printf("This is fun2!\n");
}
Create 1 head file:
head.h
void fun1();
void fun2();
Now make a static library with gcc:
gcc -c fun1.c -o fun1.o
gcc -c fun2.c -o fun2.o
ar rcs libtest1.a fun1.o fun2.o

Now I have a static library libtest1.a. If I use it in gcc compiler, there will be no problem.
Create file main.c:
#include <stdio.h>
#include "head.h"
int main()
{
  fun1();
  fun2();
  return 0;
}
Compile it(all the files are in the same directory):
gcc -o main main.c -I./ -L./ -ltest1
./main

The shell will certainly return:
This is fun1!
This is fun2!

However, how can I run build my external library with MOOSE?
I read this #24129
It said we can use ADDITIONAL_LIBS in Makefile. I put the head.h in /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_couplewithpy/include/, I put libtest1.a in /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_couplewithpy/exlib/. I edit Makefile:
# dep apps
APPLICATION_DIR    := $(CURDIR)
APPLICATION_NAME   := lianxi_couplewithpy
BUILD_EXEC         := yes
GEN_REVISION       := no
ADDITIONAL_LIBS    :="-I/home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_couplewithpy/include/ -L/home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_couplewithpy/exlib/ -ltest1"
include            $(FRAMEWORK_DIR)/app.mk
and call fun1(), fun2() in my MOOSE code. However, it seems that #24129 does not work in my computer.
I
conda activate moose
make

and the shell returns
Checking if header needs updating: /home/sjtu/projects/moose/framework/include/base/MooseRevision.h...
Linking Executable /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_couplewithpy/lianxi_couplewithpy-opt...
/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/10.4.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_couplewithpy/lib/liblianxi_couplewithpy-opt.so: undefined reference to `fun1()'
/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/10.4.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_couplewithpy/lib/liblianxi_couplewithpy-opt.so: undefined reference to `fun2()'

make: *** [/home/sjtu/projects/moose/framework/app.mk:445: /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_couplewithpy/lianxi_couplewithpy-opt] Error 1

Where is my fault? Could somebody explain it to me?

Could you define both ADDITIONAL_INCLUDES, and ADDITIONAL_LIBS as

ADDITIONAL_LIBS     := /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_couplewithpy/exlib/libltest1.a

ADDITIONAL_INCLUDES := "/home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_couplewithpy/include"

The shell returns with errors...
/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/10.4.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_mf/src/.libs/main.x86_64-conda-linux-gnu.opt.o: in function `main':
main.C:(.text.startup.main+0x88): undefined reference to `fun1()'
/home/sjtu/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/10.4.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: main.C:(.text.startup.main+0x8e): undefined reference to `fun2()'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
make: *** [/home/sjtu/projects/moose/framework/app.mk:456: /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_mf/lianxi_mf-opt] Error 1

So where I made mistakes?
How to link external libraries to a MOOSE application like gcc?

You should modify your app s Makefile instead of the framework app.mk and build.mk.
You should use the ADDITIONAL_..._FLAGS variables to pass these additional flags you added.

I try  this problem again. These are the best answers for linking external libraries:

The -I(head files directory) options have better be added after the ADDITIONAL_CPPFLAGS variable in Makefile of user's MOOSE app.
The -L(library files directory), -l(library files names without 'lib' and '.a')
options have better be added after the ADDITIONAL_LIBS variable in Makefile of user's MOOSE app.
In my example,  I put the head.h declaring void fun1() and void fun2() in /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_couplewithpy/include/, I put library file libtest1.a defining void fun1() and void fun2() in /home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_couplewithpy/exlib/. I should put these in Makefile of user's MOOSE app. (The name of user's MOOSE app in this example is lianxi_couplewithpy)

# dep apps
APPLICATION_DIR    := $(CURDIR)
APPLICATION_NAME   := lianxi_couplewithpy
BUILD_EXEC         := yes
GEN_REVISION       := no
#This is realized by $(FRAMEWORK_DIR)/app.mk
ADDITIONAL_CPPFLAGS+=-I/home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_couplewithpy/include/
#This is realized by $(FRAMEWORK_DIR)/build.mk
ADDITIONAL_LIBS+=-L/home/sjtu/projects/lianxi_couplewithpy/exlib/
ADDITIONAL_LIBS+=-ltest1
include            $(FRAMEWORK_DIR)/app.mk
After this, the C++ code of MOOSE with #include "head.h"can call the function void fun1() and void fun2() of libtest1.a directly.
Thanks for following this discussion with me!

ok this is more what I expect.
Thank you for figuring this out on your own and posting the solution!

node.title: Mutliscale Modeling

node.bodyText:
If I am understanding well, you just need a way to plug your local stress based on some parameters.

Can I modify this material module and equate the last _S[qp] with my average stress from micro?

In a way, yes. You need to understand what you need from MOOSE to obtain your local stress, i.e. _S[qp] and then create your stress material. In that case, your stress won't be NeoHookean, just the stress you compute from your microscale problem. One example of "micro" model plugged into the engineering scale simulations is the following object:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/tensor_mechanics/src/materials/LAROMANCEStressUpdateBase.C. But this object inherits from radial return, which may or may not be what you want.

node.title: [PorousFlow] - Single Phase - Multicomponent flow - density/ viscosity
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I am trying to simulate a single phase - two component system as mixed flow of a fluid and with a higher density fluid.
Since I assume that I have a component with a mass fraction > 0.1 , I consider that rho and mu changes due to the mass concentration and I also have to consider this in the flow equations.
I have therefore written my own material inspired by the material PorousFlowBrine, which calculates rho/mu as a function of p_T_x by means of a FluidProperties UserObject. Correspondingly I added also a MultiComponentFluidProperties Userobject that contains the mixture properties equations for this and which is coupled to a SinglePhase object e.g. for water.
So I can successfully derive the mixture properties for rho/mu which I successfully solve using the Kernels of PorousFlowMassTimeDerivative and PorousFlowAdvectiveFlux for both variables of mass_fraction0 and pore_pressure.
Since of course the convergence through the density and viscosity contrasts is not too good, I assume that I have to include their derivatives wrt X as well. To transfer these from the user object into the material and to fill the local (*_ddensity_dx)[_qp] with it, worked so far. Now I'm stuck on how to get them into the corresponding flux kernels. I do not understand how the corresponding derivatives (drho_dX and dmu_dX) in the MaterialProperties vectors are structured and filled in dependence of the phase and components. The structure of PorousFlow is not simple in this respect.
Therefore I wanted to ask if there is any further documentation or good examples (code as well as input files)? Or do I have a mistake in thinking and don't need these properties at all?

Well, this is a little embarrassing. I was about to say that it should be easy but just had a quick look and I don't think we are actually passing those derivatives wrt mass fraction from porousflowbrine...
I'll fix this up this weekend so that it should just work for your case. Thanks for bringing this to our attention!
Hopefully #23611 fixes this for you!
#23611 is in so this should work for you now using a PorousFlowMultiComponentFluid material.

Hi Chris,
thanks for the update and also finally to get it merged.
Yes, that¨s what I need.
Best

Hi @1runer,
Your UserObject may be really helpful for me. Any chance that you can merge it to MOOSE or share it?
Thanks!

node.title: Correct reference to WASP libraries
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I have some difficulties linking WASP to MOOSE as the default libraries pulled out from 'setup_libtorch.sh' does not seem to link when building moose.
The libraries from framework/contrib/wasp/install/lib are listed here.

Possibly some of these might need renamed to 'libwasp.so' for moose to interpret correctly at compile time. I tried doing this for libwaspcore.so.4 and it worked. Wanted to know from you the right way to get these libraries to be referenced from moose.
Thanks and regards,
Arun
@brandonlangley

@abarun22 -
Is there a reason you are not using the recommended Conda environment route for the WASP libraries?
Using the Conda route, these WASP shared libraries should exist in $WASP_DIR/lib on your Linux box:
libwaspcore.so -> libwaspcore.so.4.0.3
libwaspcore.so.04 -> libwaspcore.so.4.0.3
libwaspcore.so.4.0.3
libwaspddi.so -> libwaspddi.so.4.0.3

libwaspddi.so.4.0.3
libwaspexpr.so -> libwaspexpr.so.4.0.3
libwaspexpr.so.04 -> libwaspexpr.so.4.0.3
libwaspexpr.so.4.0.3
libwasphalite.so -> libwasphalite.so.4.0.3
libwasphalite.so.04 -> libwasphalite.so.4.0.3
libwasphalite.so.4.0.3
libwasphit.so -> libwasphit.so.4.0.3
libwasphit.so.04 -> libwasphit.so.4.0.3
libwasphit.so.4.0.3
libwasphive.so -> libwasphive.so.4.0.3
libwasphive.so.04 -> libwasphive.so.4.0.3
libwasphive.so.4.0.3
libwaspjson.so -> libwaspjson.so.4.0.3
libwaspjson.so.04 -> libwaspjson.so.4.0.3
libwaspjson.so.4.0.3
libwasplsp.so -> libwasplsp.so.4.0.3
libwasplsp.so.04 -> libwasplsp.so.4.0.3
libwasplsp.so.4.0.3
libwaspsiren.so -> libwaspsiren.so.4.0.3
libwaspsiren.so.04 -> libwaspsiren.so.4.0.3
libwaspsiren.so.4.0.3
libwaspson.so -> libwaspson.so.4.0.3
libwaspson.so.04 -> libwaspson.so.4.0.3
libwaspson.so.4.0.3
You see that these libwasp*.so symbolic links are in the WASP libraries from the Conda environment:
libwaspcore.so -> libwaspcore.so.4.0.3
libwaspddi.so -> libwaspddi.so.4.0.3
libwaspexpr.so -> libwaspexpr.so.4.0.3
libwasphalite.so -> libwasphalite.so.4.0.3
libwasphit.so -> libwasphit.so.4.0.3
libwasphive.so -> libwasphive.so.4.0.3
libwaspjson.so -> libwaspjson.so.4.0.3
libwasplsp.so -> libwasplsp.so.4.0.3
libwaspsiren.so -> libwaspsiren.so.4.0.3
libwaspson.so -> libwaspson.so.4.0.3
So unless you using HPC and cannot go this route, I recommend using Conda as described here for WASP:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html
If you cannot use Conda and need to manually install WASP, then those libwasp*.so links should still exist.
I know nothing about setup_libtorch.sh, but it shouldn't have any bearing on the installed WASP libraries.
Again if you can't use WASP from the Conda environment and need to do an offline install, could you try to:

remove the contents of the framework/contrib/wasp directory
run the ./scripts/update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh script
use ls -ltr framework/contrib/wasp/install/lib to see if those libwasp*.so links were installed

HI @brandonlangley ,
The coda way of installing moose and its dependencies does not come with out any difficulties, as hearing from other users, it is may not be the nicest way dealing with build stuffs and so i have never given a thought about it.
On the wasp building, that script i was mentioning does set up the libtorch components and not the wasp as such. Apologies for that, as i got mixed-up between these build errors in my moose environment.
The wasp build script, as i can see, creates the library components along with the symbolic links needed for the linker. However in my case it sill does not reference these components installed in 'framework/contrib/wasp/install/lib' throwing the following error. FYI, this path is referenced in both WASP_DIR  and LD_LIBRARY_PATH for moose to be able to pick at the link time.
[ir-bala2@login-q-2 mooseApp]$ make -j10

***ERROR***
WASP does not seem to be available.
Make sure to either run scripts/update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh in your MOOSE directory,
or set WASP_DIR to a valid WASP install
make: *** [/home/ir-bala2/moose_dev/moose/framework/moose.mk:375: wasp_submodule_status] Error 1


I do not see any issues with the components either as these were correctly linked to their symbolic names.

You might've better suggestions for fixing this issue that seems quite straight-forward.
Kind regards,
Arun

You might have a goofed install. Try the following (from the moose root):
cd framework
git clean -xfdq
cd ..
git submodule deinit -f framework/contrib/wasp
MOOSE_JOBS=10 ./scripts/update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh
cd test
make -j 10

This'll clean up everything in the framework

@abarun22 -
Actually, this looks problematic to me:
$> echo $WASP_DIR
/home/ir-bala2/moose dev/moose/framework/contrib/wasp/install/lib

The WASP_DIR variable is supposed to point to $(MOOSE_DIR)/framework/contrib/wasp/install.
In your case this would be /home/ir-bala2/moose dev/moose/framework/contrib/wasp/install without the lib subdirectory.
How / where is this WASP_DIR environment variable being set for you? Are you setting that yourself somehow?
You should not have to set that manually since your WASP install is in the normal place from update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh.
Because this line in moose.mk will set it correctly to that path (without the lib subdirectory) if it is not already set:
WASP_DIR            ?= $(MOOSE_DIR)/framework/contrib/wasp/install

That's pretty much the issue and sorted now.
Thanks @brandonlangley and @loganharbour
I was setting that manually as i could not test it with the wasp install script, which might require a same 'terminal' building of moose. Good to check that although.

found the bug. I ll message here when I have the patch

so recover is disabled because we only use EBSD data for mesh generation I think.
When do you use it during the simulation?

I only use it to generate the initial condition, after that when I recover I wanted it to just load from the checkpoint and continue from there.  So to recover do I instead need to set up more like a restart with a new input that loads all the nemesis/exodus data at the final timestep of the first simulation?

I dont think so? I would think the Checkpoint is the way to go.
But the data is being queried after the initial condition. It looks like after 5 non linear iterations? The GrainTracker is using it.
Did you try the fix I suggested (deleting those 3 lines)? Did it work?
Oh I didn't see that, sorry.  Yes, that seems to solve the problem, thank you so much!
While this fix seems reasonable, another alternative and perhaps a more logically correct way to do this would be to store off the information required by the mesh generator in the MeshData system.

node.title: Any restrictions on using MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE colleagues,
Do we have any resctrictions on using MOOSE license regarding the users' background, such as countries from Iran etc.?
Anyone from the world can freely use MOOSE, right? Thank you.
Best regards,
John

Open source licenses do not discriminate against different people, groups, or organizations. As long as the end user works within the bounds of the applicable license, in MOOSE's case that's LGPLv2.1, then our software can be used around the world.

node.title: "Fatal" warning during MOOSE update
node.bodyText:
I'm trying to do a Conda/Mamba and MOOSE update and got the following when attempting to do the git rebase:

(moose) eshelton@K0214:~$ cd /projects/moose
(moose) eshelton@K0214:/projects/moose$ git fetch origin
remote: Enumerating objects: 19833, done.
remote: Counting objects: 100% (12117/12117), done.
remote: Compressing objects: 100% (2079/2079), done.
remote: Total 19833 (delta 10437), reused 11338 (delta 9968), pack-reused 7716
Receiving objects: 100% (19833/19833), 17.08 MiB | 8.36 MiB/s, done.
Resolving deltas: 100% (14937/14937), completed with 1892 local objects.
From https://github.com/idaholab/moose
c9f69be..c5bcc5d  master                   -> origin/master

[new branch]            2023-11-08-release       -> origin/2023-11-08-release
[new branch]            assembly-refactors-25666 -> origin/assembly-refactors-25666
e8c7f09..c835ce5  devel                    -> origin/devel
9f83051..3833a5c  next                     -> origin/next
c9f69be..c5bcc5d  scheduled                -> origin/scheduled
[new branch]            thm-joss-paper-review    -> origin/thm-joss-paper-review
[new tag]               2023-11-08               -> 2023-11-08
(moose) eshelton@K0214:~/projects/moose$ git rebase origin/master
First, rewinding head to replay your work on top of it...
error: Updating the following directories would lose untracked files in them:
modules/heat_conduction/src

Aborting
fatal: Could not detach HEAD
(moose) eshelton@K0214:~/projects/moose$

The "Aborting" and "fatal" messages don't look like good news!
I don't think I've ever had a problem like this before running the git fetch and rebase commands.
Has the MOOSE update procedure changed, or is there a problem here.
Is it safe for me to proceed with the clobberall and make in my project directory, or is this likely to fail if the git update didn't work?

Hello
Did you put work in the heat conduction module?
That module was renamed to heat transfer. The rebase should have worked but maybe it got confused because of the sym links we now have in the former heat conduction module.
How many commits are we talking about here? Could we consider doing this manually?
Is this branch public?
Guillaume

Hello Guillaume - and Happy New Year!
It's possible some custom files have been added, but I don't think so.  I'm pretty sure any new kernels, etc. have been added in my application rather than the overarching MOOSE folder.
I don't have a module called heat transfer, so I assume haven't done an update since before this change was implemented.
I've got a more recent installation on a different computer, so I'll take a look at that to so if that has the heat transfer module instead.
I'm not sure what the question about commits means?  In the block of text it says "Enumerating obects: 19833", etc.
The branch isn't public, or at least shouldn't be.
Ed

But "make -j8" throws up this error a couple of times before stopping:

It looks like this could be something different from the heat_transfer module, maybe?

Did you make cleanall in between both builds? Having objects from the two modules won't help
I was asking about the number of commits that you added on top of your previous moose branch. If not too many, it would not be difficult to move them manually
So are you all set using a new version of moose without rebasing?

ok the errors are unrelated to heat transfer / heat conduction actually
/home/timodel01/projects/moose//framework/contrib/hit/parse.cc:687:34: error: 'class wasp::HITNodeView' has no member named 'token_type'; did you mean 'set_type'?
687 | auto token_type = value_node.token_type();

this is from WASP. You ll want to update your conda packages if you are using that.
If not then you ll need to run update_and_rebuild_wasp

I've done both "conda update --all" and "mamba update --all".  It still results in the same error when trying to run make in my applications folder.
How and in what folder should I run update_and_rebuild_wasp?

I d delete mamba and re-install with conda.
We actually made the switch from mambaforge to miniforge so it would not be surprising to have difficulties download new packages
OK.  Thanks.  I'll work with colleagues who know more about the software operating systems behind MOOSE to try to resolve these problems.

How and in what folder should I run update_and_rebuild_wasp?

This should be done in the moose/scripts folder. But not if you are using conda. If you are using conda, the conda-downloaded packages will include moose-wasp.
If they dont, the conda update is failing. And the easiest way to fix it are either a new conda environment or simply wipe conda and install it again. Since we also transitioned from mambaforge to miniforge, I would recommend the latter

If you choose to reinstall Conda, please be sure to re-follow our instructions: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html
There is a one-liner folks seems to forget: conda update --all immediately after installing Conda. This is necessary to get the very latest actual version of conda which has the correct package solver in it.

Hi - I was able to get a colleague to help me do a complete removal and reinstall of MOOSE and the supporting software package management tools on both my laptop and shared desktop, so this is all sorted now.  Thanks again for the advice and help.
Ed

node.title: How to request an object to be executed only between two power iterations?
node.bodyText:
How can I set the execute_on parameter to ensure that the target object is only executed between two power iterations of InversePowerMethod? It may not be execute_on=NONLINEAR because InversePowerMethod might not necessarily involve the concept of NONLINEAR. Otherwise, why would the operation of computing the source term |Bx| require the execute_on to include LINEAR, when it actually only needs to be executed between separate power iterations?
Any assistance will be appreciated.

Hello
Seems like we would need a new execute_on flag to do that.
Can you print a verbose log with the power iterations, the nonlienar iterations, and the execution of MOOSE objects in between?
You can use this to detect execution btw
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/userobjects/MessageFromInput.html
or the Debug flags.
Guillaume

Thank you very much for your suggestion. Following your advice, I used the show_execution_order = 'LINEAR NONLINEAR' command to output some information about the execution order. I still observe NONLINEAR operations which are next to LINEAR operations in the InversePowerMethod. As I am using an SN program with numerous variables, the output is quite lengthy, making it inconvenient to share here.
Although I still have one question at the moment, I can explore and test on my own. Great appreciation is owed to you. If you're interested, feel free to continue reading the following content, and I can also inform you about the results of subsequent tests if you wish.
In each power iteration, Petsc is essentially solving an Ax=b problem. Despite InversePowerMethod being an eigenvalue solver, the eigenvalue solution is independent of Petsc. The vector b contains information from the previous power iteration's eigenvalue and variable solutions. The object I intend to create is an acceleration algorithm, and I want this object to be executed before b is passed into Petsc. According to the documentation, when execute_on=NONLINEAR, the object is executed before Jacobian evaluation. However, I still cannot determine whether it happens before or after b is imported into Petsc.

the object is executed before Jacobian evaluation

both on nonlinear iterations and on power iterations right? So it does not work for you.
I think the way forward for now is to hardcode the execution of the objects in the Eigenvalue executioner.
Maybe @loganharbour or @YaqiWang will see an easier solution to execute on power iterations
Note that we prefer the Eigenvalue executioner over InversePowerMethod. The latter will be removed sometime in the future
